translated: It has hands and feet everywhere, eyes, heads and faces everywhere,

original: sarvataḥ śrutimal loke sarvam āvṛtya tiṣṭhati ////🔽śrīdharaḥ / nanv evaṃ brahmaṇaḥ sadasadvilakṣaṇatve sati sarvaṃ khalv idaṃ brahma
analyzed: sarvatas śrutimat loke sarvam āvṛtya tiṣṭhati
translated: ears everywhere in the world, it stands pervading everything.🔽Sridhar: Now, if Brahman is thus different from existence and non-existence, it would contradict the Upanisadic texts such as All this is indeed Brahman

original: brahmaivedaṃ sarvam ity ādiśrutibhir virudhyeta ity āśaṅkya parāsya śaktir vividhaiva
analyzed: brahma eva idam sarvam iti ādi śrutibhiḥ virudhyeta iti āśaṅkya parā asya śaktiḥ vividhā eva
translated: Brahman alone is all this etc. Thinking thus, (the Lord) says: Its power is manifold,

original: śrūyate svābhāvikī jñānabalakriyā ca ity ādi śrutiprasiddhayācintyaśaktyā sarvātmatāṃ
analyzed: śrūyate svābhāvikī jñāna bala kriyā ca iti ādi śruti prasiddhayā acintya śaktyā sarva ātma tām
translated: heard to be natural, of knowledge, strength and action etc. By the inconceivable power well-known from the Upanisads, (Brahman) has the nature of being all.

original: tasya darśayann āha sarvata iti pañcabhiḥ /🔽sarvataḥ sarvatra pāṇayaḥ pādāś ca yasya tat /
analyzed: tasya darśayan āha sarvatas iti pañcabhiḥ  sarvatas sarvatra pāṇayaḥ pādāḥ ca yasya tat
translated: Showing that, he says with the five words beginning with 'sarvataḥ' (everywhere).🔽That which has hands and feet everywhere is it.

original: sarvato 'kṣīṇi śirāṃsi mukhāni ca yasya tat /
analyzed: sarvatas kṣīṇi śirāṃsi mukhāni ca yasya tat
translated: That which has eyes, heads and faces everywhere is it.

original: sarvataḥ śrutimat śravaṇendriyair yuktaṃ salloke sarvam āvṛtya vyāpya tiṣṭhati /
analyzed: sarvatas śrutimat śravaṇa indriyaiḥ yuktam sat loke sarvam āvṛtya vyāpya tiṣṭhati
translated: That which is endowed with hearing everywhere, with ears, stands pervading all the world.

original: sarvaprāṇivṛttibhiḥ pāṇyādibhir upādhibhiḥ sarvavyavahārāspadatvena tiṣṭhatīty arthaḥ ////
analyzed: sarva prāṇi vṛttibhiḥ pāṇi ādibhiḥ upādhibhiḥ sarva vyavahāra āspada tvena tiṣṭhati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it stands as the basis of all transactions by means of the limiting adjuncts such as hands etc., the activities of all living beings.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /🔽evaṃ nirupādhikasya brahmaṇaḥ sacchabdapratyayāviṣayatvād asattvāśaṅkāyāṃ nāsad
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ  evam nirupādhikasya brahmaṇaḥ sat śabda pratyaya aviṣaya tvāt asattva āśaṅkāyām na asat
translated: Madhusudana.

original: ity anenāpāstāyām api vistareṇa tadāśaṅkānivṛttyarthaṃ sarvaprāṇikaraṇopādhidvāreṇa
analyzed: iti anena apāstāyām api vistareṇa tad āśaṅkā nivṛtti artham sarva prāṇi karaṇa upādhi dvāreṇa
translated: Thus, because Brahman, which is without limiting adjuncts, is not the object of the word 'sat' and the idea of existence, even though non-existence is refuted by the words 'na asat' (not non-existent), in order to remove that doubt in detail,

original: cetanakṣetrajñarūpatayā tadastitvaṃ pratipādayann āha sarvata iti /
analyzed: cetana kṣetrajña rūpa tayā tad astitvam pratipādayan āha sarvatas iti
translated: he says 'sarvataḥ' (everywhere) etc. to teach its existence in the form of the conscious Kshetrajna through the limiting adjuncts of all the organs of all living beings.

original: sarvataḥ sarveṣu deheṣu pāṇayaḥ pādāś cācetanāḥ svasvavyāpāreṣu pravartanīyā ysays cetanasya kṣetrajṇasya tat sarvataḥ pāṇipādaṃ jñeyaṃ
analyzed: sarvatas sarveṣu deheṣu pāṇayaḥ pādāḥ ca acetanāḥ sva sva vyāpāreṣu pravartanīyāḥ cetanasya kṣetrajṇasya tat sarvatas pāṇi pādam jñeyam
translated: That which has hands and feet everywhere, i.e. in all bodies, the unconscious hands and feet which are to be engaged in their respective activities, of the conscious Kshetrajna, that should be known as having hands and feet everywhere.

original: sarvācetanapravṛttīnāṃ cetanādhiṣṭhānapūrvakatvāt tasmin kṣetrajñe cetane brahmaṇi jñeye sarvācetanavargapravṛttihetau nāsti nāstitāśaṅkety
analyzed: sarva acetana pravṛttīnām cetana adhiṣṭhāna pūrvaka tvāt tasmin kṣetrajñe cetane brahmaṇi jñeye sarva acetana varga pravṛtti hetau na asti nāstitā śaṅkā iti
translated: The meaning is that there is no doubt of non-existence in that Brahman, the knower of the field, the conscious one, the cause of the activity of the entire class of insentient things, the one who is to be known.

original: arthaḥ /
analyzed: arthaḥ
translated: Thus, the meaning is that there is no doubt of non-existence in that Brahman, the knower of the field, the conscious one, the cause of the activity of the entire class of insentient things, the one who is to be known.

original: evaṃ sarvato 'kṣīṇi śirāṃsi mukhāni ca yasya pravartanīyāni santi tat sarvato 'kṣiśiromukhaṃ /
analyzed: evam sarvatas kṣīṇi śirāṃsi mukhāni ca yasya pravartanīyāni santi tat sarvatas kṣi śiraḥ mukham
translated: Similarly, that which has eyes, heads, and faces on all sides, which are to be set in motion, is the one with eyes, heads, and faces on all sides.

original: evaṃ sarvataḥ śrutayaḥ śravaṇendriyāṇi yasya pravartanīyatvena santa tat sarvataḥ śrutimat /
analyzed: evam sarvatas śrutayaḥ śravaṇa indriyāṇi yasya pravartanīya tvena tat sarvatas śrutimat
translated: Similarly, that which has ears, the organs of hearing, on all sides, which are to be set in motion, is the one with ears on all sides.

original: loke sarvaprāṇinikāye /
analyzed: loke sarva prāṇi nikāye
translated: In the world, in the entire class of living beings.

original: ekam eva nityaṃ vibhu ca sarvam acetanavargam āvṛtya svasattayā sphūrtyā cādhyāsikena sambandhena vyāpya tiṣṭhati nirvikāram eva sthitiṃ labhate /
analyzed: ekam eva nityam vibhu ca sarvam acetana vargam āvṛtya sva sattayā sphūrtyā ca ādhyāsikena sambandhena vyāpya tiṣṭhati nirvikāram eva sthitim labhate
translated: The one and only eternal and all-pervading Brahman, having enveloped the entire class of insentient things with its own existence and manifestation, remains pervading them with an adventitious relation, attaining a state of immutability itself.

original: na tu svādhyastasya jaḍaprapañcasya doṣeṇa guṇena vāṇumātreṇāpi sambadhyata ity arthaḥ / yathā
analyzed: na tu sva adhyastasya jaḍa prapañcasya doṣeṇa guṇena vā aṇu mātreṇa api sambadhyate iti arthaḥ yathā
translated: The meaning is that it is not connected with even an atom of the fault or quality of the inert world superimposed upon it, just as

original: ca sarveṣu deheṣv ekam eva cetanaṃ nityaṃ vibhu ca na pratidehaṃ bhinnaṃ tathā prapañcitaṃ prāk ////
analyzed: ca sarveṣu deheṣu ekam eva cetanam nityam vibhu ca na pratideham bhinnam tathā prapañcitam prāk
translated: it has been elaborately explained earlier that the one and only conscious being is eternal and all-pervading in all bodies, not different for each body.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /🔽nanv evaṃ brahmaṇaḥ sadasadvilakṣaṇatve sati sarvaṃ khalv idaṃ brahma brahmaivedaṃ🔽sarvam ity ādiśrutir virudhyeta ity āśaṅkya svarūpataḥ kāryakāraṇātītatve 'pi śaktiśaktimator
analyzed: nanu evam brahmaṇaḥ sat asat vilakṣaṇa tve sati sarvam khalu idam brahma brahma eva idam  sarvam iti ādi śrutiḥ virudhyeta iti āśaṅkya svarūpataḥ kārya kāraṇa atīta tve pi śakti śaktimatoḥ
translated: Visvanatha.

original: abhedāt kāryakāraṇātmakam api tad ity āha sarvata eva pāṇayaḥ pādāś ca yasya tat /
analyzed: abhedāt kārya kāraṇa ātmakam api tat iti āha sarvatas eva pāṇayaḥ pādāḥ ca yasya tat
translated: Now, if Brahman is thus different from existence and non-existence, then the Upanisadic text All this is Brahman and Brahman alone is all this etc. would be contradicted. Anticipating this doubt, he says that although it is beyond effects and causes in its nature, it is also of the nature of effects and causes because of the non-difference of the power and the possessor of the power. It is so because it has hands and feet everywhere.

original: brahmādipipīlikāntānāṃ pāṇipādavṛndaiḥ sarvatra dṛṣṭair eva tad brahmaivāsaṅkhyapāṇipādair yuktm ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: brahma ādi pipīlika antānām pāṇi pāda vṛndaiḥ sarvatra dṛṣṭaiḥ eva tat brahma eva asaṅkhya pāṇi pādaiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that Brahman is endowed with innumerable hands and feet, since it is seen everywhere with multitudes of hands and feet of all beings from Brahma down to ants.

original: evam eva sarvato 'kṣīty ādi ///
analyzed: evam eva sarvatas kṣīti ādi
translated: In the same way, it has eyes everywhere etc.

original: baladevaḥ / atha paramātmavastūpadiśati sarvataḥ pāṇīti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ atha paramātma vastu upadiśati sarvatas pāṇī iti
translated: Balarama. Now he teaches the reality of the supreme Self, beginning with It has hands and feet everywhere.

original: tat paramātmavastu /
analyzed: tat paramātma vastu
translated: That is the reality of the supreme Self.

original: sarvataḥ pāṇipādam ity ādi visphuṭārtham ////
analyzed: sarvatas pāṇi pādam iti ādi visphuṭa artham
translated: The meaning of It has hands and feet everywhere etc. is clear.

original: BhG /🔽sarvendriyaguṇābhāsaṃ sarvendriyavivarjitam /
analyzed: bhg  sarva indriya guṇa ābhāsam sarva indriya vivarjitam
translated: BhG.🔽It manifests the qualities of all the senses, yet is devoid of all the senses.

original: asaktaṃ sarvabhṛc caiva nirguṇaṃ guṇabhoktṛ ca ////
analyzed: asaktam sarva bhṛt ca eva nirguṇam guṇa bhoktṛ ca
translated: It is unattached, yet supports all, is qualityless, yet the experiencer of the qualities.

original: śrīdharaḥ / kiṃ casarvendriyeti /
translated: Sridhara. Moreover, it is said to have all the senses.

original: sarveṣāṃ cakṣurādīnāṃ guṇeṣu rūpādyākārāsu vṛttiṣu tattadākāreṇa bhāsate iti tathā /
analyzed: sarveṣām cakṣuḥ ādīnām guṇeṣu rūpa ādi ākārāsu vṛttiṣu tad tad ākāreṇa bhāsate iti tathā
translated: And it shines forth in the form of each of them, i.e., in the form of the eye, etc., in the qualities, and in the functions having the form of color, etc.

original: sarvendriyāṇi guṇāṃś ca tattadviṣayān ābhāsayatīti vā /
analyzed: sarva indriyāṇi guṇān ca tad tad viṣayān ābhāsayati iti vā
translated: Or, it shines forth in all the sense organs and in the qualities that are the objects of each of them.

original: sarvaiḥ indriyair vivarjitaṃ ca /
analyzed: sarvaiḥ indriyaiḥ vivarjitam ca
translated: And it is devoid of all sense organs.

original: tathā ca śrutiḥ apāṇipādo javano grahītā paśyaty acakṣuḥ sa śṛṇoty akarṇaḥ ity ādiḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ a pāṇi pādaḥ javanaḥ grahītā paśyati a cakṣuḥ sa śṛṇoti a karṇaḥ iti ādiḥ
translated: And thus the scripture says, It is without hands and feet, yet it moves swiftly and grasps. It sees without eyes, it hears without ears. And so on.

original: asaktaṃ saṅgaśūnyam /
analyzed: asaktam saṅga śūnyam
translated: It is unattached, devoid of attachment.

original: tathāpi sarvaṃ bibhartīti sarvasyādhārabhūtam /🔽tad eva nirguṇaṃ sattvādiguṇarahitaṃ /
analyzed: tathā api sarvam bibharti iti sarvasya ādhāra bhūtam  tat eva nirguṇam sattva ādi guṇa rahitam
translated: Yet it supports everything, thus it is the basis of everything.🔽That itself is without qualities, devoid of the qualities of sattva, etc.

original: guṇabhoktṛ ca guṇānāṃ sattvādīnāṃ bhoktṛ pālakam ////
analyzed: guṇa bhoktṛ ca guṇānām sattva ādīnām bhoktṛ pālakam
translated: And it is the enjoyer of the qualities, the protector of the qualities such as sattva.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /🔽adhyāropāpavādābhyāṃ niṣprapañcaṃ prapañcyate iti nyāyam anusṛtya sarvaprapañcādhyāropeṇānādimat
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ  adhyāropa apavādābhyām niṣprapañcam prapañcyate iti nyāyam anusṛtya sarva prapañca adhyāropeṇa anādimat
translated: Madhusudana.🔽Following the principle that the non-proliferation is proliferated by superimposition and negation, it has been explained as the supreme Brahman, which is beginningless and

original: paraṃ brahmeti vyākhyātam adhunā tadapavādena na sat tan nāsad ucyate iti vyākhyātum
analyzed: param brahma iti vyākhyātam adhunā tad apavādena na sat tat na asat ucyate iti vyākhyātum
translated: has no qualities. Now, in order to explain it as That is neither existent nor non-existent is said,

original: ārabhate nirupādhisvarūpajñānāya sarvendriyeti /
analyzed: ārabhate nirupādhi svarūpa jñānāya sarva indriya iti
translated: beginning with By all the sense organs... for the knowledge of the nature free from limiting adjuncts.

original: paramārthataḥ sarvendriyavivarjitaṃ tanmāyayā sarvendriyaguṇābhāsaṃ sarveṣāṃ bahiṣkaraṇānāṃ
analyzed: paramārthataḥ sarva indriya vivarjitam tat māyayā sarva indriya guṇa ābhāsam sarveṣām bahiṣkaraṇānām
translated: In reality, it is devoid of all sense organs, but by māyā it appears to have the qualities of all sense organs, and it appears as if engaged in the activities of all sense organs,

original: śrotrādīnām antaḥkaraṇayoś ca buddhimanasor guṇair adhyavasāyasaṅkalpaśravaṇavacanādibhis🔽tattadviṣayarūpatayāvabhāsata iva sarvendriyavyāpārair vyāpṛtam iva taj jñeyaṃ
analyzed: śrotra ādīnām antaḥkaraṇayoḥ ca buddhi manasoḥ guṇaiḥ adhyavasāya saṅkalpa śravaṇa vacana ādibhiḥ  tat tat viṣaya rūpa tayā avabhāsate iva sarva indriya vyāpāraiḥ vyāpṛtam iva tat jñeyam
translated: such as hearing, speaking, etc., through the qualities of the internal organs like intellect and mind, like the object of knowledge.

original: brahma dhyāyatīva lelāyatīva BAU / / iti śruteḥ /🔽atra dhyānaṃ buddhīndriyavyāpāropalakṣaṇam /
analyzed: brahma dhyāyati iva lelāyati iva bau  iti śruteḥ  atra dhyānam buddhīndriya vyāpāra upalakṣaṇam
translated: This is because of the Vedic text: It seems to meditate and move as if it were Brahman.🔽Here, meditation is a metaphor for the activities of the cognitive sense organs.

original: lelāyanaṃ calanaṃ karmendriyavyāpāropalakṣaṇārtham /
analyzed: lelāyanam calanam karmendriya vyāpāra upalakṣaṇa artham
translated: Moving is a metaphor for the activities of the action sense organs.

original: tathā paramārthato 'saktaṃ sarvasambandhaśūnyam eva /
analyzed: tathā saktam sarva sambandha śūnyam eva
translated: Similarly, in reality, it is unattached and devoid of all connections,

original: māyayā sarvabhṛc ca sadātmanā sarvaṃ kalpitaṃ dhārayatīva poṣayatīti ca sarvabhṛt /
analyzed: māyayā sarva bhṛt ca sat ātmanā sarvam kalpitam dhārayati iva poṣayati iti ca sarva bhṛt
translated: but by māyā it appears to sustain all that is imagined as having the nature of the self, and it appears to nourish all, thus it is the sustainer of all.

original: niradhiṣṭhānabhramāyogāt /
analyzed: niradhiṣṭhāna bhrama ayogāt
translated: Because it is not possible for an illusion to be without a basis.

original: tathā paramārthato nirguṇaṃ sattvarajastamoguṇarahitam eva /
analyzed: tathā paramārthataḥ nirguṇam sattva rajaḥ tamaḥ guṇa rahitam eva
translated: Similarly, in reality, it is devoid of qualities, free from the qualities of sattva, rajas, and tamas,

original: guṇabhoktṛ ca guṇānāṃ sattvarajastamasāṃ śabdādidvārā sukhaduḥkhamohākāreṇa pariṇatānāṃ bhoktṛ upalabdhṛ ca taj jñeyaṃ brahmety arthaḥ
analyzed: guṇa bhoktṛ ca guṇānām sattva rajaḥ tamasām śabda ādi dvārā sukha duḥkha moha ākāreṇa pariṇatānām bhoktṛ upalabdhṛ ca tat jñeyam brahma iti arthaḥ
translated: And the enjoyer of the qualities, the enjoyer of the qualities of sattva, rajas and tamas, which manifest in the form of pleasure, pain and delusion through sound etc., and the experiencer. That Brahman is to be known. This is the meaning.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: kiṃ ca sarvāṇi indriyāṇi guṇān indriyaviṣayāṃś ca ābhāsayatīti tac cakṣuṣaś cakṣuḥ ity ādi śruteḥ /
analyzed: kim ca sarvāṇi indriyāṇi guṇān indriya viṣayān ca ābhāsayati iti tat cakṣuṣaḥ cakṣuḥ iti ādi śruteḥ
translated: Moreover, it illuminates all the senses and the objects of the senses. That is the eye of the eye, etc., according to the Upanisadic text.

original: yad vā sarvendriyair guṇaiḥ śabdādibhiś cābhāsate virājatīti tat /
analyzed: yat vā sarva indriyaiḥ guṇaiḥ śabda ādibhiḥ ca ābhāsate virājati iti tat
translated: Or, it shines with all the senses and the qualities like sound, etc. That is so.

original: tad api sarvendriyavivarjitaṃ prākṛtendriyādirahitam /
analyzed: tat api sarva indriya vivarjitam prākṛta indriya ādi rahitam
translated: That also is devoid of all senses, free from the natural senses etc.

original: tathā ca śrutiḥ apāṇipādo javano grahītā paśyaty acakṣuḥ sa śṛṇoty akarṇaḥ ity ādi /
analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ a pāṇi pādaḥ javanaḥ grahītā paśyati a cakṣuḥ sa śṛṇoti a karṇaḥ iti ādi
translated: And thus the Upanisad says: It is without hands and feet, yet it moves swiftly and grasps. It sees without eyes, it hears without ears, etc.

original: parāsya śaktir bahudhaiva śrūyate svābhāvikī jñānabalakriyā ca iti śrutiprasiddhasvarūpaśaktyāspadatvād iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: parā asya śaktiḥ bahudhā eva śrūyate svābhāvikī jñāna bala kriyā ca iti śruti prasiddha svarūpa śakti āspada tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is the abode of the inherent power of Brahman, which is well-known from the Upanisads as Its power is heard in many ways, naturally, as knowledge, strength and action.

original: asaktaṃ āsaktiśūnyaṃ sarvabhṛt śrīviṣṇusvarūpeṇa sarvapālakam /
analyzed: asaktam āsakti śūnyam sarva bhṛt śrī viṣṇu sva rūpeṇa sarva pālakam
translated: Unshakable, free from attachment, the supporter of all, the protector of all in the form of Lord Vishnu.

original: nirguṇaṃ sattvādiguṇarahitākāram /
analyzed: nirguṇam sattva ādi guṇa rahita ākāram
translated: Devoid of qualities, free from the forms of sattva etc. qualities.

original: kiṃ ca guṇabhoktṛ triguṇātītabhagaśabdavācā ṣaḍguṇāsvādakam ////
analyzed: kim ca guṇa bhoktṛ triguṇa atīta bhaga śabda vācā ṣaḍguṇa āsvādakam
translated: Moreover, the enjoyer of the qualities, who is beyond the three qualities, is the one referred to by the word Lord, who tastes the six qualities.

original: baladevaḥ / kiṃ ca sarveti sarvair indriyair guṇaiś ca tadvṛttibhir ābhāsate dīpyata
analyzed: baladevaḥ kim ca sarva iti sarvaiḥ indriyaiḥ guṇaiḥ ca tad vṛttibhiḥ ābhāsate dīpyata
translated: Balarama. Moreover, the one who shines with all the senses and their functions, who is illuminated by all the senses and their functions,

original: iti tathā sarvair indriyair jīvendriyavat svarūpabhinnair vivarjitaṃ santyaktaṃ
analyzed: iti tathā sarvaiḥ indriyaiḥ jīva indriya vat sva rūpa bhinnaiḥ vivarjitam san tyaktam
translated: is thus described. The one who is devoid of all the senses and their functions, who has abandoned them,

original: prākṛtaiḥ karaṇaiḥ śūnyaḥ svarūpānubandhibhis tair viśiṣṭo harir iti svīkāryam /
analyzed: prākṛtaiḥ karaṇaiḥ śūnyaḥ sva rūpa anubandhibhiḥ taiḥ viśiṣṭaḥ hariḥ iti svīkāryam
translated: who is devoid of the natural instruments, who is distinguished by those that are connected with his own nature, that Hari should be accepted.

original: apāṇipādo javano grahītā paśyaty acakṣuḥ sa śṛṇoty akarṇaḥ /
analyzed: a pāṇi pādaḥ javanaḥ grahītā paśyati a cakṣuḥ sa śṛṇoti a karṇaḥ
translated: He who has no hands or feet, who is swift, who grasps, who sees without eyes, who hears without ears,

original: yad ātmako bhagavāṃs tadātmikā vyaktiḥ kim ātmako bhagavān jñānātmaka aiśvaryātmakaḥ🔽śaktyātmakaś ceti buddhimano 'ṅgapratyaṅgavattāṃ bhagavato lakṣayāmahe buddhimān
analyzed: yad ātmakaḥ bhagavān tad ātmikā vyaktiḥ kim ātmakaḥ bhagavān jñāna ātmakaḥ aiśvarya ātmakaḥ  śakti ātmakaḥ ca iti buddhi manaḥ ṅga pratyaṅgavat tām bhagavataḥ lakṣayāmahe buddhimān
translated: whose nature is the nature of the Supreme Lord, whose manifestation is of that nature. What is the nature of the Supreme Lord? He is of the nature of knowledge, of the nature of lordship,🔽and of the nature of power. We observe in the Lord the state of being endowed with intellect, mind, limbs, and parts,

original: manobāṇaṅgapratyaṅgavān iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: iti śruteḥ
translated: as stated in the scriptures.

original: sarvabhṛt sarvatattvadhārakam apy asaktaṃ saṅkalpenaiva taddhāraṇāt tatsparśarahitaṃ
analyzed: sarva bhṛt sarva tattva dhārakam api asaktam saṅkalpena eva tad dhāraṇāt tad sparśa rahitam
translated: The supporter of all, the upholder of all principles, yet unattached, because of upholding them by mere will, devoid of contact with them,

original: nirguṇaṃ sākṣī cetāḥ kevalo nirguṇaś ca iti śruter māyāguṇaspṛṣṭam eva sadguṇabhoktṛniyamyatayā
analyzed: nirguṇam sākṣī cetāḥ kevalaḥ nirguṇaḥ ca iti śruteḥ māyā guṇa spṛṣṭam eva sat guṇa bhoktṛ niyamya tayā
translated: The attributeless, the witness, the mind, the sole, and the attributeless, according to the śruti. Being touched by the attributes of māyā, it is the enjoyer of the attributes by being regulated.

original: guṇanubhavivikārajananīm ajñām
analyzed: guṇa anubhavi vikāra jananīm ajñām
translated: The ignorant one, the generator of modifications, experiencing the attributes,

original: ity ārabhya
analyzed: iti ārabhya
translated: beginning from here,

original: ekas tu pibate devaḥ
analyzed: ekaḥ tu pibate devaḥ
translated: The one God drinks here,

original: svacchando 'tra vaśānugām /
analyzed: svacchandaḥ tra vaśā anugām
translated: the independent one, the one who is obedient.

original: dhyānakriyābhyāṃ bhagavān
analyzed: dhyāna kriyābhyām bhagavān
translated: By meditation and action, the Lord

original: bhuṅkte 'sau prasabhaṃ vibhuḥ //
analyzed: bhuṅkte sau prasabham vibhuḥ
translated: enjoys it forcibly, the all-pervading one.

original: iti śravaṇāt ////
analyzed: iti śravaṇāt
translated: Due to this statement.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: Bhagavad Gītā.

original: bahir antaś ca bhūtānām acaraṃ caram eva ca /
analyzed: bahis antar ca bhūtānām acaram caram eva ca
translated: Outside and inside of beings, unmoving and moving,

original: sūkṣmatvāt tad avijñeyaṃ dūrasthaṃ cāntike ca tat ////
analyzed: sūkṣma tvāt tat avijñeyam dūra stham ca antike ca tat
translated: because of subtlety, it is unknowable, far away and near.

original: śrīdharaḥ / kiṃ ca bahir iti /
analyzed: ca
translated: Śrīdhara: What's more, outside, etc.

original: bhūtānāṃ carācarāṇāṃ svakāryāṇāṃ bahiś cāntaś ca tad eva suvarṇam iva kaṭakakuntalādīnām /
analyzed: bhūtānām cara acarāṇām sva kāryāṇām bahis ca antar ca tat eva suvarṇam iva kaṭaka kuntala ādīnām
translated: That very gold, like bracelets, earrings, etc., outside and inside of beings, moving and unmoving, and their own effects.

original: jalataraṅgāṇām antarbahiś ca jalam iva /
analyzed: jala taraṅgāṇām antar bahis ca jalam iva
translated: Like water, inside and outside of water waves.

original: acaraṃ sthāvaraṃ caraṃ jaṅgamaṃ ca bhūtajātaṃ tad eva /
analyzed: acaram sthāvaram caram jaṅgamam ca bhūtajātam tat eva
translated: That very moving and unmoving class of beings, unmoving and moving.

original: kāraṇātmatvāt kāryasya /
analyzed: kāraṇa ātma tvāt kāryasya
translated: Because the effect has the nature of the cause.

original: evam api sūkṣmatvād rūpādihīnatvād tad avijñeyam idaṃ tad iti spaṣṭaṃ jñānārhaṃ na bhavati /
analyzed: evam api sūkṣma tvāt rūpa ādi hīna tvāt tat avijñeyam idam tat iti spaṣṭam jñāna arham na bhavati
translated: Even so, it is unknowable because of subtlety, because of being devoid of form, etc. It does not deserve clear knowledge like this is that.

original: ataevāviduṣāṃ yojanalakṣāntaritam iva dūrasthaṃ ca /
analyzed: ataeva aviduṣām yojana lakṣa antaritam iva dūra stham ca
translated: And for that very reason, it is far away, as it were, distant by a hundred thousand leagues, for the unenlightened.

original: savikārāyāḥ prakṛteḥ paratvāt /
analyzed: sa vikārāyāḥ prakṛteḥ paratvāt
translated: Because it is beyond the transformed prakriti.

original: viduṣāṃ punaḥ pratyagātmatvād antike ca tan nityaṃ sannihitam /
analyzed: viduṣām punar pratyagātma tvāt antike ca tat nityam sannihitam
translated: But for the enlightened, it is near, because it is the inner self, and it is always present.

original: tathā ca mantraḥ
analyzed: tathā ca mantraḥ
translated: And so says the mantra:

original: tad ejati tan naijati
analyzed: tat ejati tat na ejati
translated: It moves, it does not move,

original: taddūre tad vāntike /
analyzed: tat dūre tat vā antike
translated: it is far, it is near.

original: tadantarasya sarvasya
analyzed: tad antarasya sarvasya
translated: It is within all this,

original: tad u sarvasyāsya bāhyataḥ //
analyzed: tat u sarvasya asya bāhyatas
translated: and it is outside of all this.

original: Īśopaniṣad iti /
analyzed: īśa upaniṣad iti
translated: The Isha Upanishad.

original: ejati calati naijati na calati /
analyzed: ejati calati na ejati na calati
translated: It moves, it does not move.

original: tad u antike iti cchedaḥ ////
analyzed: tat u antike iti chedaḥ
translated: The meaning of it is near is to be supplied.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: bhūtānāṃ bhavanadharmāṇāṃ sarveṣāṃ kāryāṇāṃ kalpitānām akalpitam adhiṣṭhānam ekam eva bahir antaś ca rajjur iva svakalpitānāṃ sarpadhārādīnāṃ
analyzed: bhūtānām bhavana dharmāṇām sarveṣām kāryāṇām kalpitānām akalpitam adhiṣṭhānam ekam eva bahis antar ca rajjuḥ iva sva kalpitānām sarpa dhārā ādīnām
translated: The one uncreated substratum of all created beings, all effects, is the same, both outside and inside, like a rope of the imagined snakes, ropes, etc.

original: sarvātmanā vyāpakam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: sarva ātmanā vyāpakam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it pervades everything.

original: ata evācaraṃ sthāvaraṃ caraṃ ca jañgamaṃ bhūtajātaṃ tad evādhiṣṭhānātmakatvāt /
analyzed: atas eva acaram sthāvaram caram ca jañgamam bhūta jātam tat eva adhiṣṭhāna ātmaka tvāt
translated: For that very reason, the moving and unmoving, the animate and inanimate, are that itself, because it is the substratum.

original: kalpitānāṃ na tataḥ kiṃcid vyatiricyata ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: kalpitānām na tatas kiṃcid vyatiricyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that nothing is separate from it.

original: evaṃ sarvātmaktve 'pi sūkṣmtvād rūpādihīnatvāt tadavijñeyam idam evam iti spaṣṭajñānārhaṃ na bhavati /
analyzed: evam sarva ātmak tve pi sūkṣm tvāt rūpa ādi hīna tvāt tat avijñeyam idam evam iti spaṣṭa jñāna arham na bhavati
translated: Thus, even in the state of being the Self of all, it is subtle, devoid of form etc., and is not fit to be known clearly as 'this is so'.

original: ata evātmajñānasādhanaśūnyānāṃ varṣasahasrakoṭyāpy aprāpyatvād dūrasthaṃ ca yojanalakṣakoṭyantaritam iva tat /
analyzed: atas eva ātma jñāna sādhana śūnyānām varṣa sahasra koṭyā api a prāpya tvāt dūra stham ca yojana lakṣa koṭi antaritam iva tat
translated: For this very reason, it is far away, like being separated by millions of yojanas, because it cannot be attained even in millions of years by those devoid of the means of knowing the Self.

original: jñānasādhanasampannānāṃ tu antike ca tad atyavyavahitam evātmatvāt /
analyzed: jñāna sādhana sampannānām tu antike ca tat ati avyavahitam eva ātma tvāt
translated: But for those endowed with the means of knowledge, it is near, not at all obstructed, because it is the Self.

original: dūrāt sudūre tad ihāntike paśatsv ihaiva nihitaṃ guhāyām MuṇḍU / / ity ādi śrutibhyaḥ ////
analyzed: dūrāt su dūre tat iha antike paśatsu iha eva nihitam guhāyām muṇḍu iti ādi śrutibhyaḥ
translated: It is seen to be very far away from those far away, and near in those near, hidden here itself in the cave, as stated in the Upanishads beginning with 'It is far away, very far away, and is seen here near, hidden here itself in the cave' (Tai. U. 2.7).

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: bhūtānāṃ svakāryāṇāṃ bahiś cāntaś ca yathā dehānām ākāśādikam /
analyzed: bhūtānām sva kāryāṇām bahis ca antar ca yathā dehānām ākāśa ādikam
translated: Just as space etc. are to the bodies of beings, their own effects, both outside and inside.

original: acaraṃ sthāvaraṃ caraṃ jaṅgamaṃ ca bhūtajātaṃ tad eva /
analyzed: acaram sthāvaram caram jaṅgamam ca bhūtajātam tat eva
translated: That very moving and unmoving creation.

original: kāryasya kāraṇātmakatvāt /
analyzed: kāryasya kāraṇa ātmaka tvāt
translated: Because the effect has the nature of the cause.

original: evam api rūpādibhinnatvāt tadavijñeyam idaṃ tad iti spaṣṭaṃ jñānārhaṃ na bhavatīty
analyzed: evam api rūpa ādi bhinna tvāt tat avijñeyam idam tat iti spaṣṭam jñāna arham na bhavati iti
translated: Even so, because it is different from form etc., it is not fit to be known clearly as 'this is that'.

original: ata evāviduṣāṃ yojanakoṭyantaram iva dūrasthaṃ viduṣāṃ punaḥ svagṛhasthitam evāntike
analyzed: atas eva aviduṣām yojana koṭi antaram iva dūra stham viduṣām punar sva gṛha sthitam eva antike
translated: For this very reason, it is far away, like being separated by millions of yojanas, for the ignorant, but for the wise, it is near, as if situated in their own house.

analyzed: bhūta bhartṛ ca tat jñeyam grasiṣṇu prabhaviṣṇu ca

original: anyan na bhavati /
analyzed: anyat na bhavati
translated: Among beings, consisting of the immobile and the moving, it is undivided, not different in the form of the cause. It abides as if divided, different, in the form of the effect. Like foam born from the ocean is not different from the ocean.

original: tatsvarūpam evoktaṃ jñeyaṃ bhūtānāṃ bhartṛ ca poṣakaṃ sthitikāle /
analyzed: tad svarūpam evā uktam jñeyam bhūtānām bhartṛ ca poṣakam sthiti kāle
translated: It is the very form of that. It should be known as the supporter of beings, nourishing them at the time of persistence.

original: pralayakāle ca grasiṣṇu grasanaśīlaṃ sṛṣṭikāle ca prabhaviṣṇu nānākāryātmanā prabhavanaśīlam ////
analyzed: pralaya kāle ca grasiṣṇu grasana śīlam sṛṣṭi kāle ca prabhaviṣṇu nānā kārya ātmanā prabhavana śīlam
translated: And at the time of dissolution, it is all-devouring, inclined to swallow everything. And at the time of creation, it is all-powerful, inclined to manifest in various forms of effects.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: yad uktam ekam eva sarvam āvṛtya tiṣṭhatīti tad vivṛṇoti pratideham ātmabhedavādināṃ nirāsāya avibhaktam iti /
analyzed: yat uktam ekam eva sarvam āvṛtya tiṣṭhati iti tat vivṛṇoti pratideham ātma bheda vādinām nirāsāya avibhaktam iti
translated: He explains what was said that it exists pervading everything as one, to refute those who say that the Self is different in each body, he says undivided.

original: bhūteṣu sarvaprāṇiṣu avibhaktam abhinnam ekam eva tat /
analyzed: bhūteṣu sarva prāṇiṣu avibhaktam abhinnam ekam eva tat
translated: In all beings, in all living creatures, it is undivided, non-different, one only.

original: na tu pratidehaṃ bhinnaṃ vyomavat sarvavyāpakatvāt /
analyzed: na tu pratideham bhinnam vyoma vat sarva vyāpaka tvāt
translated: But it is not different in each body, like space, because it pervades everything.

original: tathāpi dehatādātmyena pratīyamānatvāt pratidehaṃ vibhaktam iva ca sthitam /
analyzed: tathā api deha tādātmyena pratīyamāna tvāt pratideham vibhaktam iva ca sthitam
translated: Nevertheless, because it is perceived as identical with the body, it seems to be divided in each body, as it were.

original: aupādikatvenāpāramārthiko vyomnīva tatra bhedāvabhāsa ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: aupādika tvena apāramārthikaḥ vyomni iva tatra bheda avabhāsaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The appearance of difference there is unreal, like in space, because it is adventitious. This is the meaning.

original: nanu bhavatu kṣetrajñaḥ sarvavyāpaka ekaḥ /
analyzed: nanu bhavatu kṣetrajñaḥ sarva vyāpakaḥ ekaḥ
translated: But let the individual soul be all-pervading and one.

original: brahma tu jagatkāraṇaṃ tato bhinnam eveti /
analyzed: brahma tu jagat kāraṇam tatas bhinnam eva iti
translated: But Brahman, the cause of the world, is certainly different from that.

original: nety āha bhūtabhartṛ ca bhūtāni sarvāṇi sthitikāle bibhartīti tathā pralayakāle grasiṣṇu grasanaśīlam utpattikāle prabhaviṣṇu ca prabhavanaśīlaṃ
analyzed: na iti āha bhūta bhartṛ ca bhūtāni sarvāṇi sthiti kāle bibharti iti tathā pralaya kāle grasiṣṇu grasana śīlam utpatti kāle prabhaviṣṇu ca prabhavana śīlam
translated: No, he says. It is the lord of beings, it sustains all things at the time of persistence, in the same way, at the time of dissolution, it is the devourer, inclined to devour, at the time of origination, it is the powerful one, inclined to create,

original: sarvasya /
analyzed: sarvasya
translated: of everything.

original: yathā rajjvādiḥ sarpāder māyākalpitasya /
analyzed: yathā rajju ādiḥ sarpa ādeḥ māyā kalpitasya
translated: Just as a rope, etc. is of a snake, etc. imagined by illusion.

original: tasmād yaj jagataḥ sthitilayotpattikāraṇaṃ brahma tad eva kṣetrajñaṃ pratideham ekaṃ jñeyaṃ na tato 'nyad ity arthaḥ ////
analyzed: tasmāt yat jagataḥ sthiti laya utpatti kāraṇam brahma tat eva kṣetrajñam pratideham ekam jñeyam na tatas nyat iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning is that Brahman, which is the cause of the creation, sustenance, and dissolution of the world, is the one knowable for each individual soul, and nothing else.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha:

original: bhūteṣu sthāvarajaṅgamātmakeṣu avibhaktaṃ kāraṇātmanā abhinnaṃ kāryātmanā vibhaktaṃ bhinnam ivā sthitaṃ /
analyzed: bhūteṣu sthāvara jaṅgama ātmakeṣu avibhaktam kāraṇa ātmanā abhinnam kārya ātmanā vibhaktam bhinnam iva ā sthitam
translated: Undivided among the elements, both moving and unmoving, it remains undifferentiated in its causal aspect, but differentiated, as if different, in its effect aspect.

original: tad eva śrīnārāyaṇasvarūpaṃ sat /
analyzed: tat eva śrī nārāyaṇa svarūpam sat
translated: That very form of Lord Narayana,

original: bhūtānāṃ bhartṛ sthitikāle pālakaṃ /
analyzed: bhūtānām bhartṛ sthiti kāle pālakam
translated: it is the supporter of beings during the time of sustenance, the protector.

original: pralayakāle grasiṣṇu saṃhārakam /
analyzed: pralaya kāle grasiṣṇu saṃhārakam
translated: During the time of dissolution, it is the consumer, the destroyer.

original: sṛṣṭikāle prabhaviṣṇu ca nānākāryātmanā prabhavanaśīlam ////
analyzed: sṛṣṭi kāle prabhaviṣṇu ca nānā kārya ātmanā prabhavana śīlam
translated: During the time of creation, it is the powerful one, inclined to create in various effective forms.

original: baladevaḥ / avibhaktam iti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ avibhaktam iti
translated: Balarama: Undivided.

original: vibhakteṣu mitho bhinneṣu jīveṣv avibhaktam ekaṃ tad brahma vibhaktam iva pratijīvaṃ bhinnam iva sthitam /
analyzed: vibhakteṣu mithas bhinneṣu jīveṣu avibhaktam ekam tat brahma vibhaktam iva pratijīvam bhinnam iva sthitam
translated: Among the individual souls, mutually different, that Brahman is undivided, one, but appears as if divided, as if different for each individual soul.

original: ekaṃ santaṃ bahudhā dṛśyamānam iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: ekam santam bahudhā dṛśyamānam iti śruteḥ
translated: As stated in the Upanishad: Existing as one, it is seen in many ways.

original: eka eva paro viṣṇuḥ
analyzed: ekaḥ eva paraḥ viṣṇuḥ
translated: The supreme Vishnu is indeed one,

original: sarvatrāpi na saṃśayaḥ /
analyzed: sarvatra api na saṃśayaḥ
translated: there is no doubt about this everywhere.

original: aiśvaryād rūpam ekaṃ ca
analyzed: aiśvaryāt rūpam ekam ca
translated: By His power, He has one form,

original: sūryavad bahudheyate //
analyzed: sūrya vat bahudhā iyate
translated: but appears in many ways like the sun.

original: iti smṛteś ca /
analyzed: iti smṛteḥ ca
translated: This is also stated in the Smriti.

original: tac ca bhūtabhartṛsthitau bhūtānāṃ pālakaṃ pralaye teṣāṃ grasiṣṇu kālaśaktyā saṃhārakaṃ /
analyzed: tat ca bhūta bhartṛ sthitau bhūtānām pālakam pralaye teṣām grasiṣṇu kāla śaktyā saṃhārakam
translated: And that is the protector of the beings in the state of creation, the destroyer of them at the time of dissolution by its power of time.

original: sarge prabhaviṣṇu pradhānajīvaśaktibhyāṃ nānākāryātmanā prabhavanaśīlaṃ /
analyzed: sarge prabhaviṣṇu pradhāna jīva śaktibhyām nānā kārya ātmanā prabhavana śīlam
translated: It is the powerful one in the creation by its power of primordial matter and individual souls, having the nature of various effects.

original: śrutiś ca yato vā imāni bhūtāni jāyante yena jātāni jīvanti yat prayanty abhisaṃviśanti tad brahma tad vijijñāsasva TaittU / / iti ////
analyzed: śrutiḥ ca yatas vai imāni bhūtāni jāyante yena jātāni jīvanti yat prayanti abhisaṃviśanti tat brahma tat vijijñāsasva taittu iti
translated: And the śruti says: From which these beings are born, by which they live when born, into which they enter at the time of dissolution, that is Brahman, seek to know that, O Śvetaketu.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: jyotiṣām api taj jyotis tamasaḥ param ucyate /
analyzed: jyotiṣām api tat jyotiḥ tamasaḥ param ucyate
translated: It is the light of even the lights, it is said to be beyond darkness.

original: jñānaṃ jñeyaṃ jñānagamyaṃ hṛdi sarvasya viṣṭhitam ////
analyzed: jñānam jñeyam jñāna gamyam hṛdi sarvasya viṣṭhitam
translated: It is knowledge, the object of knowledge, attainable by knowledge, and is situated in the heart of all.

original: śrīdharaḥ / kiṃ ca jyotiṣām apīti /🔽jyotiṣāṃ sūryādīnām api jyotiḥ prakāśakaṃ tat /
analyzed: jyotiṣām sūrya ādīnām api jyotiḥ prakāśakam tat
translated: Śrīdhara: And what is more, it is the light of even the lights.🔽It is the light that illuminates even the lights such as the sun etc.🔽By which the sun shines, the moon shines,

original: yena sūryas tapati tejasendhaḥ /
analyzed: yena sūryaḥ tapati tejasā indhaḥ
translated: and the fire shines.

original: na tatra sūryo bhāti na candratārakaṃ
analyzed: na tatra sūryaḥ bhāti na candra tārakam
translated: There the sun does not shine, nor the moon and stars,

original: nemā vidyuto bhānti kuto 'yam agniḥ /🔽tad eva bhāntam anubhāti sarvaṃ
analyzed: na imāḥ vidyutaḥ bhānti kutas yam agniḥ  tat eva anubhāti sarvam
translated: nor these lightnings, how then this fire?🔽All this shines following that light,

original: tasya bhāsā sarvam idaṃ vibhāti //
analyzed: tasya bhāsā sarvam idam vibhāti
translated: by whose light all this shines.

original: KaṭhU / / ity ādiśruteḥ /
analyzed: kaṭhu iti ādi śruteḥ
translated: As it is said in the Katha Upanishad etc.

original: ataeva tamaso 'jñānāt paraṃ tenāsaṃsṛṣṭam ucyate /
analyzed: ataeva tamasaḥ jñānāt param tena asaṃsṛṣṭam ucyate
translated: Therefore, it is said to be beyond darkness, i.e., ignorance, and not mixed with it.

original: ādityavarṇaṃ tamsasaḥ parastāt ity ādiśruteḥ /
analyzed: āditya varṇam tamsasaḥ parastāt iti ādi śruteḥ
translated: Because of Vedic statements such as Having the color of the sun, beyond darkness... (Tai. U. 2.1).

original: jñānaṃ ca tad eva buddhivṛttau abhivyaktam /
analyzed: jñānam ca tat eva buddhi vṛttau abhivyaktam
translated: And that itself is knowledge, manifested in the activity of the intellect.

original: tad eva rūpādyākāreṇa jñeyaṃ ca jñānagamyaṃ ca /
analyzed: tat eva rūpa ādi ākāreṇa jñeyam ca jñāna gamyam ca
translated: And that itself is the object of knowledge, in the form of color etc., and is attainable by knowledge.

original: amānitvādilakṣaṇena pūrvoktajñānasādhanena prāpyam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: amāni tva ādi lakṣaṇena pūrva ukta jñāna sādhanena prāpyam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is to be attained by the means of knowledge described earlier, such as humility etc.

original: jñānagamyaṃ viśinaṣṭi sarvasya prāṇimātrasya hṛdi viṣṭhitaṃ viśeṣeṇāpracyutasvarūpeṇa niyantṛtayā sthitam /
analyzed: jñāna gamyam viśinaṣṭi sarvasya prāṇimātrasya hṛdi viṣṭhitam viśeṣeṇa apracyuta svarūpeṇa niyantṛ tayā sthitam
translated: It distinguishes what is attainable by knowledge: it is situated in the heart of all living beings, abiding in a special way, without deviating from its own nature, as the controller.

original: dhiṣṭhitam iti pāṭhe adhiṣṭāya sthitim ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: dhiṣṭhitam iti pāṭhe adhiṣṭāya sthitim iti arthaḥ
translated: In the reading dhishthitam, the meaning is abiding after having presided over.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: nanu sarvatra vidyamānam api tan nopalabhyate cet tarhi jaḍam eva syāt /
analyzed: nanu sarvatra vidyamānam api tat na upalabhyate ced tarhi jaḍam eva syāt
translated: If it is not perceived even though it exists everywhere, then it would be inert.

original: na syāt svayaṃjyotiṣo 'pi tasya rūpādihīnatvenendriyādyagrāhyatvopapatter ity āha jyotiṣām iti /
analyzed: na syāt svayaṃjyotiṣaḥ api tasya rūpa ādi hīna tvena indriya ādi agrāhya tva upapatteḥ iti āha jyotiṣām iti
translated: It would not be so, because even that self-luminous one can be logically held to be imperceptible by the senses etc. due to its being devoid of color etc. Thus he says of the luminaries...

original: taj jñeyaṃ brahma jyotiṣām avabhāsakānām ādityādīnāṃ buddhyādīnāṃ ca bāhyānām āntarāṇām api jyotir avabhāsakaṃ caityanyajyotiṣo jaḍajyotiravabhāsakatvopapatteḥ
analyzed: tat jñeyam brahma jyotiṣām avabhāsakānām āditya ādīnām buddhi ādīnām ca bāhyānām āntarāṇām api jyotiḥ avabhāsakam ca eti anya jyotiṣaḥ jaḍa jyotiḥ avabhāsaka tva upapatteḥ
translated: That Brahman is to be known as the light of the illuminating lights, the sun etc., and the external and internal intellect etc., because it is possible for the light of Brahman to illuminate the dull lights of other lights.

original: yena sūryas tapati tejasendhaḥ /
analyzed: yena sūryaḥ tapati tejasā indhaḥ
translated: By which the sun shines, the fire glows.

original: tasya bhāsā sarvam idaṃ vibhāti KaṭhU / / ity ādiśruteś ca /
analyzed: tasya bhāsā sarvam idam vibhāti kaṭhu iti ādi śruteḥ ca
translated: By its light this all shines. Katha.

original: vakṣyati ca yad ādityagataṃ tejaḥ Gītā / ity ādi /
analyzed: vakṣyati ca yat āditya gatam tejaḥ gītāḥ iti ādi
translated: And it will be said: The light that is in the sun, Gita. etc.

original: svayaṃ jaḍatvābhāve 'pi jaḍasaṃsṛṣṭaṃ syād iti nety āha tamaso jaḍavargāt param
analyzed: svayam jaḍa tva abhāve pi jaḍa saṃsṛṣṭam syāt iti nā iti āha tamasaḥ jaḍa vargāt param
translated: Even in the absence of its own dullness, it may be mixed with the dull, to this he says: beyond the dull class, the darkness.

original: avidyātatkāryābhyām apāramārthikābhyām asaṃspṛṣṭaṃ pāramārthikaṃ tad brahma sadasatoḥ sambandhāyogāt /
analyzed: avidyā tad kāryābhyām apāramārthikābhyām a saṃspṛṣṭam pāramārthikam tat brahma sat asatoḥ sambandha ayogāt
translated: Untouched by the non-ultimate ignorance and its effects, that Brahman is the ultimate, because it cannot be related to existence and non-existence.

original: ucyate akṣarāt parataḥ paraḥ ity ādiśrutibhir brahmavādibhiś ca / tad uktam
analyzed: ucyate akṣarāt paratas paraḥ iti ādi śrutibhiḥ brahma vādibhiḥ ca tat uktam
translated: It is said by the Vedanta scholars, in the Upanisads, that Brahman is beyond the imperishable, etc. That is said:

original: niḥsaṅgasya sasaṅgena kūṭasthasya vikāriṇā /
analyzed: niḥsaṅgasya sa saṅgena kūṭasthasya vikāriṇā
translated: The union of the unattached with the attached, of the immutable with the mutable,

original: ātmano 'nātmanā yogo vāstavo nopapadyate //
analyzed: ātmanaḥ na ātmanā yogaḥ vāstavaḥ na upapadyate
translated: of the Self with the non-Self, is not really possible.

original: ādityavarṇaṃ tamasaḥ parastāt iti śruteś ca /
analyzed: āditya varṇam tamasaḥ parastāt iti śruteḥ ca
translated: And because of the Upanisadic text: Having the color of the sun, beyond darkness.

original: ādityavarṇam iti svabhāne prakāśāntarānapekṣaṃ sarvasya prakāśakam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: āditya varṇam iti sva bhāne prakāśa antara anapekṣam sarvasya prakāśakam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the expression 'having the colour of the sun' is that it is self-luminous, and illuminates everything else without depending on any other light.

original: yasmāt tat svayaṃ jyotir jaḍāsaṃspṛṣṭam ata eva taj jñānaṃ pramāṇajanyacetovṛttyabhivyaktasaṃvidrūpam /
analyzed: yasmāt tat svayam jyotiḥ jaḍa a saṃspṛṣṭam atas eva tat jñānam pramāṇa janya cetaḥ vṛtti abhivyakta saṃvid rūpam
translated: Since it is self-luminous and not in contact with the inert, therefore, that knowledge is of the nature of consciousness manifested by the mental activity produced by the means of knowledge.

original: ata eva tad eva jñeyaṃ jātum arham ajñātatvāj jaḍasyājñātatvābhāvena jñātum anarhatvāt /
analyzed: atas eva tat eva jñeyam jātum arham ajñāta tvāt jaḍasya ajñāta tva abhāvena jñātum anarha tvāt
translated: For this very reason, that alone is fit to be known, because it is unknown. The inert is not fit to be known, because it is not unknown.

original: kathaṃ tarhi sarvair na jñāyate tatrāha jñānagamyaṃ pūrvoktenāmānitvādinā tattvajñānārthadarśanāntena
analyzed: katham tarhi sarvaiḥ na jñāyate tatra āha jñāna gamyam pūrva uktena amāni tva ādinā tattva jñāna artha darśana antena
translated: If it is asked how it is not known by all, the answer is that it is to be reached by knowledge, by the aggregate of means mentioned earlier, beginning with 'not being proud' and ending with 'seeing the meaning of the knowledge of reality',

original: sādhanakalāpena jñānahetutayā jñānaśabditena gamyaṃ prāpyaṃ na tu tad vinety arthaḥ /
analyzed: sādhana kalāpena jñāna hetutayā jñāna śabditena gamyam prāpyam na tu tat vinā iti arthaḥ
translated: which is called knowledge because it is the cause of knowledge. It is to be reached, not without that.

original: nanu sādhanena gamyaṃ cet tat kiṃ deśāntaravyavahitam /
analyzed: nanu sādhanena gamyam ced tat kim deśa antara vyavahitam
translated: If it is to be reached by the means, is it then obstructed by a different place?

original: nety āha hṛdi sarvasya viṣṭhitaṃ sarvasya prāṇijātasya hṛdi buddhau viṣṭhitaṃ sarvatra
analyzed: na iti āha hṛdi sarvasya viṣṭhitam sarvasya prāṇi jātasya hṛdi buddhau viṣṭhitam sarvatra
translated: No, it is said: 'Dwelling in the heart of all', in the intellect of all living beings, it exists everywhere

original: sāmānyena sthitam api viśeṣarūpeṇa tatra sthitam abhivyaktaṃ jīvarūpeṇāntaryāmirūpeṇa ca /
analyzed: sāmānyena sthitam api viśeṣa rūpeṇa tatra sthitam abhivyaktam jīva rūpeṇa antaryāmi rūpeṇa ca
translated: in a general way, but it exists there in a particular form, manifested in the form of the individual soul and the immanent soul.

original: sauraṃ teja ivādarśasūryakāntādau /
analyzed: sauram tejaḥ iva ādarśa sūryakānta ādau
translated: Like the solar light in a mirror, the sun-crystal, etc.

original: avyavahitam eva vastuto bhrāntyā vyavahitam iva sarvabhramakāraṇājñānanivṛttyā prāpyata ivety arthaḥ ////
analyzed: avyavahitam eva vastutas bhrāntyā vyavahitam iva sarva bhrama kāraṇa ajñāna nivṛttyā prāpyate iva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is actually unobstructed, but is attained as if obstructed by the removal of the ignorance that is the cause of all error.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /🔽jyotiṣāṃ candrādityānām api taj jyotiḥ prakāśakaṃ /
analyzed: jyotiṣām candra ādityānām api tat jyotiḥ prakāśakam
translated: Visvanatha.🔽That light is the illuminator of even the luminaries, the moon and the sun.

original: yena sūryas tapati tejasendhaḥ /
analyzed: yena sūryaḥ tapati tejasā indhaḥ
translated: By which the sun shines, the carrier of light and fuel.

original: na tatra sūryo bhāti na candratārakaṃ
analyzed: na tatra sūryaḥ bhāti na candra tārakam
translated: There the sun does not shine, nor the moon and stars,

original: nemā vidyuto bhānti kuto 'yam agniḥ /🔽tad eva bhāntam anubhāti sarvaṃ
analyzed: na imāḥ vidyutaḥ bhānti kutas yam agniḥ  tat eva anubhāti sarvam
translated: Nor these lightnings shine, how much less this fire.🔽All this shines following that which shines.

original: tasya bhāsā sarvam idaṃ vibhāti //
analyzed: tasya bhāsā sarvam idam vibhāti
translated: By its light all this shines.

original: KaṭhU / / ity ādiśruteḥ /
analyzed: kaṭhu iti ādi śruteḥ
translated: As stated in the Katha Upanishad, etc.

original: ata eva tamaso 'jñānāt paraṃ tenāsaṃsṛṣṭam ucyate /
analyzed: atas eva tamasaḥ jñānāt param tena asaṃsṛṣṭam ucyate
translated: For this very reason, it is said to be beyond darkness, ignorance, unmixed with it.

original: ādityavarṇaṃ tamsasaḥ parastāt ity ādiśruteḥ /
analyzed: āditya varṇam tamsasaḥ parastāt iti ādi śruteḥ
translated: As stated in the scriptures, Beyond that which is of the color of the sun, beyond darkness, etc.

original: jñānaṃ tad eva buddhivṛttau abhivyaktaṃ sat jñānam ucyate /
analyzed: jñānam tat eva buddhi vṛttau abhivyaktam sat jñānam ucyate
translated: That itself, when manifested in the modifications of the intellect, is called knowledge.

original: tad eva rūpādyākāreṇa pariṇataṃ jñeyaṃ ca /
analyzed: tat eva rūpa ādi ākāreṇa pariṇatam jñeyam ca
translated: That same [knowledge], transformed into the form of color etc., is the object of knowledge.

original: tad eva jñānagamyaṃ pūrvoktenāmānitvādijñānasādhanena prāpyam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: tat eva jñāna gamyam pūrvoktena amāni tva ādi jñāna sādhanena prāpyam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is to be attained by knowledge, by the means of attaining knowledge such as non-egoity etc. mentioned earlier.

original: tad eva paramātmasvarūpaṃ sat sarvasya prāṇimātrasya hṛdi dhiṣṭhitaṃ niyantṛtayādhbiṣṭhāya sthitam ity arthaḥ ////
analyzed: tat eva paramātma svarūpam sat sarvasya prāṇimātrasya hṛdi dhiṣṭhitam niyantṛ tayā adhbiṣṭhāya sthitam iti arthaḥ
translated: That alone, which is the nature of the Supreme Self, exists, and is present in the heart of all living beings, as the controller, i.e. it exists as the controller.

original: baladevaḥ / jyotiṣāṃ sūrydīnām api tad brahma jyotiḥ prakāśakaṃ /
analyzed: baladevaḥ jyotiṣām sūry dīnām api tat brahma jyotiḥ prakāśakam
translated: Balarama: That Brahman is the light of the luminaries like the sun etc., the illuminator.

original: na tatra sūryo bhāti na candratārakaṃ
analyzed: na tatra sūryaḥ bhāti na candra tārakam
translated: There the sun does not shine, nor the moon and stars,

original: nemā vidyuto bhānti kuto 'yam agniḥ /
analyzed: na imāḥ vidyutaḥ bhānti kutas yam agniḥ
translated: nor these lightnings, much less this fire.

original: tad eva bhāntam anubhāti sarvaṃ
analyzed: tat eva anubhāti sarvam
translated: All this shines following that which shines,

original: tasya bhāsā sarvam idaṃ vibhāti // KaṭhU / /🔽ity ādiśrutes tad brahma /
analyzed: tasya bhāsā sarvam idam vibhāti kaṭhu  iti ādi śruteḥ tat brahma
translated: by whose light all this shines. Katha Upanishad🔽 Thus it is said in the scriptures, that Brahman is that.

original: tad brahma tamasaḥ prakṛteḥ paraṃ tenāspṛṣṭam ucyate ādityavarṇaṃ tamasaḥ parastāt ŚvetU / ity śrutyā /🔽jñānaṃ cidekarasam ucyate vijñānam ānandaghanaṃ brahma GTU / / iti śrutyā /
analyzed: tat brahma tamasaḥ prakṛteḥ param tena a spṛṣṭam ucyate āditya varṇam tamasaḥ parastāt śvetu iti śrutyā  jñānam cit eka rasam ucyate vijñānam ānanda ghanam brahma gtu iti śrutyā
translated: That Brahman is said to be beyond the darkness (ignorance), untouched by it, as stated in the Upanishad: Having the color of the sun, beyond darkness, white.🔽Knowledge, which is of the nature of pure consciousness, is said to be Brahman, which is full of bliss, as stated in the Upanishad: Brahman is knowledge, full of bliss.

original: jñānaṃ mumukṣoḥ śaraṇatvena jñātum arham ucyate taṃ ha devam ātmabuddhiprakāśaṃ mumukṣur vai śaraṇam ahaṃ prapadye GTU / iti śrutyā
analyzed: jñānam mumukṣoḥ śaraṇa tvena jñātum arham ucyate tam ha devam ātma buddhi prakāśam mumukṣuḥ vai śaraṇam aham prapadye iti śrutyā
translated: Knowledge, which is to be known as the refuge of the seeker of liberation, is said to be worthy of being known, as stated in the Upanishad: I, the seeker of liberation, go for refuge to that God, the light of the knowledge of the Self.

original: jñānagamyam ucyate tam eva viditvātimṛtyum eti ŚvetU / iti śrutyā /
analyzed: jñāna gamyam ucyate tam eva viditvā atimṛtyum eti śvetu iti śrutyā
translated: He is said to be knowable through knowledge. Knowing Him alone, one goes beyond death, O Śvetaketu. (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 8.15.1) by this Vedic text.

original: sarvasya prāṇimātrasya hṛdi dhiṣṭhitaṃ niyantṛtayādhiṣṭhāya sthitam ity ucyate antaḥpraviṣṭaḥ śāstā janānām TaittĀ / / iti śrutyā /
analyzed: sarvasya prāṇimātrasya hṛdi dhiṣṭhitam niyantṛ tayā adhiṣṭhāya sthitam iti ucyate antar praviṣṭaḥ śāstā janānām taittā iti śrutyā
translated: It is said that He abides in the heart of all living beings as the controller, overseeing them. He who is the inner controller, the Lord of all beings, (Bhagavad Gītā 18.61) by this Vedic text.

original: na ca sarvataḥ pāṇīty ādi pañcakaṃ jīvaparatayaiva neyaṃ tatprakaraṇatvādivācyaṃ jīvavad īśvarasyāpi kṣetrajñatvena prakṛtatvāt /
analyzed: na ca sarvatas pāṇi iti ādi pañcakam jīva para tayā eva neyam tad prakaraṇa tva ādi vācyam jīva vat īśvarasya api kṣetrajña tvena prakṛta tvāt
translated: And the set of five beginning with having hands and feet everywhere should not be interpreted only in terms of the individual soul, because it is the topic of that [set of five], and because the Lord is also the subject, being the knower of the field like the individual soul.

original: sarvataḥ pāṇīty ādisārdhakasya brahmaivopakramya
analyzed: sarvatas pāṇi iti ādi sārdhakasya brahmā eva upakramya
translated: The set of five beginning with having hands and feet everywhere is introduced as Brahman itself,

original: śvetāśvataraiḥ paṭhitvāt prakaraṇaśāvalyasyopaniṣatsu vīkṣaṇāc ca ////
analyzed: śvetāśvataraiḥ paṭhitvāt prakaraṇa śāvalyasya upaniṣatsu vīkṣaṇāt ca
translated: because it is recited by the Śvetaketu Aśvatarāyana school, and because the context is seen to be the Upaniṣads.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: Bhagavad Gītā

original: iti kṣetraṃ tathā jñānaṃ jñeyaṃ coktaṃ samāsataḥ /
analyzed: iti kṣetram tathā jñānam jñeyam ca uktam samāsatas
translated: Thus the field, knowledge, and the knowable have been succinctly stated.

original: madbhakta etad vijñāya madbhāvāyopapadyate ////
analyzed: mad bhaktaḥ etat vijñāya mad bhāvāya upapadyate
translated: My devotee, knowing this, becomes fit for union with Me.

original: śrīdharaḥ / uktaṃ kṣetrādikam adhikāriphalasahitam upasaṃharati itīti /
translated: Śrīdhara: To conclude the field, etc., along with the qualifications and results, he says thus.

original: ity enaṃ kṣetraṃ mahābhūtādidhṛtyantam /
analyzed: iti enam kṣetram mahābhūta ādi dhṛti antam
translated: Thus, this field ends with the great elements and the earth.

original: tathā jñānaṃ cāmānitvāditattvajñānārthadarśanāntam /
analyzed: tathā jñānam ca amāni tva ādi tattva jñāna artha darśana antam
translated: Similarly, knowledge, beginning with freedom from pride and ending with the vision of the truth of the knowledge of reality,

original: jñeyaṃ cānādimat paraṃ brahmety ādi viṣṭhitam ity antam /
analyzed: jñeyam ca anādimat param brahma iti ādi viṣṭhitam iti antam
translated: and the object of knowledge, beginning with the beginningless supreme Brahman and ending with the statement it is established,

original: vasiṣṭhādibhir vistareṇoktaṃ sarvam api mayā saṅkṣepeṇoktam /
analyzed: vasiṣṭha ādibhiḥ vistareṇa uktam sarvam api mayā saṅkṣepeṇa uktam
translated: all of which has been stated in detail by Vasistha and others, has been stated by me in brief.

original: etac ca katham /
analyzed: etat ca katham
translated: And how is this?

original: pūrvādhyāyoktalakṣaṇo madbhakto vijñāya madbhāvāya brahmatvāyopapadyate yogyo bhavati ////
analyzed: pūrva adhyāya ukta lakṣaṇaḥ mad bhaktaḥ vijñāya mad bhāvāya brahmatvāya upapadyate yogyaḥ bhavati
translated: One who is devoted to me, having understood the characteristics stated in the previous chapter, becomes fit for attaining my state, for becoming Brahman.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: uktaṃ kṣetrādikam adhikāriṇaṃ phalaṃ ca vadann upasaṃharati itīti /
analyzed: uktam kṣetra ādikam adhikāriṇam phalam ca vadan upasaṃharati iti iti
translated: Stating the field and so on, the person entitled to it, and the result, he concludes with the word iti (thus).

original: iti anena pūrvoktena prakāreṇa kṣetraṃ mahābhūtādidhṛtyantaṃ /
analyzed: iti anena pūrva uktena prakāreṇa kṣetram mahābhūta ādi dhṛti antam
translated: Thus, by this previously stated method, the field ends with the earth, the great elements, and so on.

original: tathā jñānam amānitvādi tattvajñānārthadarśanaparyantaṃ /
analyzed: tathā jñānam amāni tva ādi tattva jñāna artha darśana paryantam
translated: Similarly, knowledge ends with freedom from pride and the vision of the truth of the knowledge of reality.

original: jñeyaṃ cānādimat paraṃ brahma viṣṭhitam ity antaṃ śrutibhyaḥ smṛtibhyaś cākṛṣya trayam api mandabuddhyanugrahāya mayā saṃkṣepenoktam /
analyzed: jñeyam ca anādimat param brahma viṣṭhitam iti antam śrutibhyaḥ smṛtibhyaḥ ca ākṛṣya trayam api manda buddhi anugrahāya mayā saṃkṣepena uktam
translated: And the object of knowledge, beginning with the beginningless supreme Brahman and ending with the statement it is established, all three have been stated by me in brief for the benefit of those of slow intellect, having extracted them from the scriptures and the Smritis.

original: etāvān eva hi sarvo vedārtho gītārthaś ca /
analyzed: etāvān eva hi sarvaḥ veda arthaḥ gīta arthaḥ ca
translated: For this much alone is the meaning of all the Vedas and the Gita.

original: asmiṃś ca pūrvādhyāyoktalakṣaṇo madbhakta evādhikārīty āha madbhakto mayi bhagavati
analyzed: asmin ca pūrva adhyāya ukta lakṣaṇaḥ mad bhaktaḥ eva adhikārī iti āha mad bhaktaḥ mayi bhagavati
translated: And in this (verse), he says that only one who has the characteristics mentioned in the previous chapter and is devoted to Me is qualified:🔽My devotee, who is devoted to Me, the Supreme Lord,

original: vāsudeve paramagurau samarpitasarvātmabhāvo madekaśaraṇaḥ sa etad yathoktaṃ
analyzed: vāsudeve parama gurau samarpita sarva ātma bhāvaḥ mad eka śaraṇaḥ saḥ etat yathā uktam
translated: And in this (verse), he says that only one who is devoted to Me, who has the characteristics mentioned in the previous chapter, is qualified. He who is devoted to Me, who has dedicated his entire being to Lord Vāsudeva, the supreme Guru, who is solely dependent on Me, he, having understood

original: kṣetraṃ jñānaṃ ca jñeyaṃ ca vijñāya vivekena viditvā madbhāvāya sarvānarthaśūnyaparamānandabhāvāya
analyzed: kṣetram jñānam ca jñeyam ca vijñāya vivekena viditvā mad bhāvāya sarva anartha śūnya paramānanda bhāvāya
translated: this said field, knowledge, and the knowable, having known them with discrimination, for the sake of becoming one with Me, for the sake of the state of supreme bliss devoid of all evil,

original: mokṣāyopapadyate mokṣaṃ prāptuṃ yogyo bhavati /
analyzed: mokṣāya upapadyate mokṣam prāptum yogyaḥ bhavati
translated: becomes fit for liberation, becomes capable of attaining liberation.

original: yasya deve parā bhaktiḥ yathā deve tathā gurau /
analyzed: yasya deve parā bhaktiḥ yathā deve tathā gurau
translated: For one who has supreme devotion to God, and likewise to the Guru as to God,

original: tasyaite kathitā hy arthāḥ prakāśante mahātmanaḥ //
analyzed: tasya ete kathitāḥ hi arthāḥ prakāśante mahātmanaḥ
translated: the meanings of these are revealed to that magnanimous one.

original: ŚvetU / iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: iti śruteḥ
translated: As stated in the Śvetāśvatara Upaniṣad.

original: tasmāt sarvadā madekaśaraṇaḥ sann ātmajñānasādhanāny eva paramapuruṣārthalipsur anuvartate tucchaviṣayabhogaspṛhāṃ hitvety abhiprāyaḥ
analyzed: tasmāt sarvadā mad eka śaraṇaḥ san ātma jñāna sādhanāni eva parama puruṣa artha lipsuḥ anuvartate tuccha viṣaya bhoga spṛhām hitvā iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: Therefore, always being solely dependent on Me, desiring the supreme human goal, he follows only the means of knowledge of the Self, abandoning desire for worldly pleasures. This is the intention.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Viśvanātha.

original: uktaṃ kṣetrādikam adhikāriphalasahitam upasaṃharati itīti /
analyzed: uktam kṣetra ādikam adhikāri phala sahitam upasaṃharati iti iti
translated: He concludes the said field etc. along with the qualifications and fruits, with the word 'iti'.

original: kṣetraṃ mahābhūtādi dhṛtyantam /
analyzed: kṣetram mahābhūta ādi dhṛti antam
translated: The field is from the great elements to the earth.

original: jñānam amānitvāditattvajñānārthadarśanāntam /
analyzed: jñānam amāni tva ādi tattva jñāna artha darśana antam
translated: Knowledge is from non-conceit up to the vision of the truth of the knowledge of reality.

original: jñeyaṃ jñānagamyaṃ ca anādīty ādi dhiṣṭhitam ity antam /
analyzed: jñeyam jñāna gamyam ca anādi iti ādi dhiṣṭhitam iti antam
translated: The knowable and the knowledge to be attained are from beginningless up to established.

original: ekam eva tattvaṃ brahma bhagavatparamātmaśabdavācyaṃ ca saṅkṣepeṇoktam /
analyzed: ekam eva tattvam brahma bhagavat paramātma śabda vācyam ca saṅkṣepeṇa uktam
translated: The one reality is spoken of concisely as Brahman, the Supreme Lord, and the Supreme Self.

original: madbhakto bhaktimaj jñānī madbhāvāya matsāyujyāya /
analyzed: mad bhaktaḥ bhaktimat jñānī mad bhāvāya mad sāyujyāya
translated: The devotee of Mine, who is devoted to Me, who is wise, is for becoming of the nature of Mine, for union with Me.

original: yad vā madbhakto mamaikāntiko dāsa etad vijñāya matprabhor etāvad aiśvaryam iti jñātvā mayi bhāvāya premṇa upapadyata upapanno bhavati ////
analyzed: yat vā mad bhaktaḥ mama aikāntikaḥ dāsaḥ etat vijñāya mad prabhoḥ etāvat aiśvaryam iti jñātvā mayi bhāvāya premṇe upapadyate upapannaḥ bhavati
translated: Or, the devotee of Mine, who is solely devoted to Me, who is a servant, having known this, that the Lord of Mine has such Lordship, having known this, becomes fit, becomes qualified, for becoming of the nature of Mine, for love of Me.

original: baladevaḥ / uktaṃ kṣetrādikaṃ tajjñānaphalasahitam upasaṃharati iti kṣetram iti /
translated: Balarama. Having described the field etc. along with the result of the knowledge of that, he concludes with Thus the field.

original: mahābhūtāni ity ādinā cetanā dhṛtir ity antena kṣetrasvarūpam uktam /
analyzed: mahābhūtāni iti ādinā cetanā dhṛtiḥ iti antena kṣetra svarūpam uktam
translated: By The great elements etc. up to Consciousness is the support, the nature of the field has been described.

original: amānitvam ity ādinā tattvajñānārthadarśanam ity antena jñeyasya kṣetradvayasya jñānaṃ tatsādhanam uktam /
analyzed: amāni tvam iti ādinā tattva jñāna artha darśanam iti antena jñeyasya kṣetra dvayasya jñānam tad sādhanam uktam
translated: By Non-conceit etc. up to The vision of the truth of the knowledge of reality, the knowledge of the two fields, the knowable, and the means to that knowledge, have been described.

original: anādi matparam ity ādinā hṛdi sarvasya viṣṭhitam ity antena jñeyaṃ kṣetrajñadvayaṃ coktaṃ mayā /
analyzed: anādi mad param iti ādinā hṛdi sarvasya viṣṭhitam iti antena jñeyam kṣetrajña dvayam ca uktam mayā
translated: By the words beginning with 'without beginning' and ending with 'established in the heart of all', the two knowable and knowers of the field have been spoken of by Me.

original: etat trayaṃ vijñāya mitho vivekenāvagatya madbhāvāya matpremṇe matsvabhāvāya vāsaṃsāritvāya kalpate yogye bhavati madbhaktaḥ ////
analyzed: etat trayam vijñāya mithas vivekena avagatya mad bhāvāya mad premṇe mad svabhāvāya vā asaṃsāri tvāya kalpate yogye bhavati mad bhaktaḥ
translated: Having understood this triad by distinguishing them from each other, the devotee of Mine becomes fit for becoming of the nature of Mine, for the love of Mine, for the nature of Mine, for being not subject to worldly existence.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: prakṛtiṃ puruṣaṃ caiva viddhy anādī ubhāv api /
analyzed: prakṛtim puruṣam ca eva viddhi anādī ubhau api
translated: Know both Prakriti and Purusha to be without beginning.

original: vikārāṃś ca guṇāṃś caiva viddhi prakṛtisaṃbhavān ////
analyzed: vikārān ca guṇān ca eva viddhi prakṛti saṃbhavān
translated: And know the modifications and the qualities to be born of Prakriti.

original: śrīdharaḥ / tad evaṃ tat kṣetraṃ yac ca yādṛk cety etāvat prapañcitam /
analyzed: evam       ca   ca iti
translated: Sridhar: Thus, the field and what it is like have been elaborated so far.

original: idānīṃ tu yad vikāri yataś ca yat sa ca yo yatprabhāvaś cety etat pūrvaṃ pratijñātam eva prakṛtipuruṣayoḥ saṃsārahetukatvakathanena prapañcayati
analyzed: idānīm tu yat vikāri yatas ca yat sa ca yaḥ yad prabhāvaḥ ca iti etat pūrvam pratijñātam eva prakṛti puruṣayoḥ saṃsāra hetuka tva kathanena prapañcayati  /
translated: Now, what is modified, from what, what it is, and what its power is - this was previously promised and is elaborated by explaining the cause of worldly existence of Prakriti and Purusha.

original: prakṛtim iti pañcabhiḥ /
analyzed: prakṛtim iti pañcabhiḥ
translated: With five verses beginning with 'Prakriti'.

original: tatra prakṛtipuruṣayor ādimatve tayor api prakṛtyantareṇa bhāvyam ity anavasthāpattiḥ syāt /
analyzed: tatra prakṛti puruṣayoḥ ādima tve tayoḥ api prakṛti antareṇa bhāvyam iti anavasthā āpattiḥ syāt
translated: If Prakriti and Purusha were beginningless, then there would be the fault of infinite regress, as there would have to be another Prakriti for them also.

original: atas tāv ubhāv anādī viddhi /
analyzed: atas tau ubhau anādī viddhi
translated: Therefore, know both of them to be without beginning.

original: anāder īśvarasya śaktitvāt prakṛter anāditvam /
analyzed: anādeḥ īśvarasya śakti tvāt prakṛteḥ anādi tvam
translated: Since God is without beginning, Prakriti also is without beginning, because of its being His power.

original: puruṣe 'pi tadaṃśatvād anādir eva /
analyzed: puruṣe pi tad aṃśa tvāt anādiḥ eva
translated: And since the Purusha also is a part of Him, it is without beginning.

original: atra ca parameśvarasya tacchaktīnām anāditvaṃ nityatvaṃ ca śrīmacchaṅkarabhagavadbhāṣyakṛdbhir atiprabandhenopapāditam iti granthabāhulyān
analyzed: atra ca parameśvarasya tad śaktīnām anādi tvam nitya tvam ca śrīmat śaṅkara bhagavat bhāṣya kṛdbhiḥ ati prabandhena upapāditam iti grantha bāhulyān
translated: And here, the beginninglessness and eternality of the Supreme Lord and His powers have been established by the revered commentators of the Bhagavadgita, Shankara and others, in great detail. Therefore,

original: nāsmābhiḥ pratanyate /
analyzed: na asmābhiḥ pratanyate
translated: it is not repeated by us for fear of prolixity.

original: vikārāṃś ca dehendriyādīn guṇāṃś ca guṇapariṇāmān sukhaduḥkhamohādīn prakṛteḥ sambhūtān viddhi ////
analyzed: vikārān ca deha indriya ādīn guṇān ca guṇa pariṇāmān sukha duḥkha moha ādīn prakṛteḥ sambhūtān viddhi
translated: Know that the modifications, such as the body, senses, etc., and the qualities, such as happiness, sorrow, delusion, etc., which are the transformations of the qualities, originate from Prakriti.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /🔽tad anena granthena tat kṣetraṃ yac ca yādṛk ca ity etad vyākhyātam /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ  tat anena granthena tat kṣetram yat ca yādṛś ca iti etat vyākhyātam
translated: Madhusudana.🔽This passage explains the field, what it is and how it is.

original: idānīṃ yadvikāri yataś ca yat sa ca yo yatprabhāvaś ca ity etāvad vyākhyātavyam /
analyzed: idānīm yad vikāri yatas ca yat sa ca yaḥ yad prabhāvaḥ ca iti etāvat vyākhyātavyam
translated: Now, what is modified from what, and what it is, and who is that, and whose power it is, this much remains to be explained.

original: tatra prakṛtipuruṣayoḥ saṃsārahetutvakathanena yadvikāri yataś ca yad iti prakṛtim ity ādi dvābhyāṃ prapañcyate /
analyzed: tatra prakṛti puruṣayoḥ saṃsāra hetu tva kathanena yat vikāri yatas ca yat iti prakṛtim iti ādi dvābhyām prapañcyate
translated: There, by stating that Prakriti and Purusha are the causes of worldly existence, it is elaborated by the two verses beginning with Prakriti - what is modified from what, and what it is.

original: sa ca yo yat prabhāvaś ca iti tu puruṣa ity ādi dvyābhyām iti vivekaḥ /
analyzed: sa ca yaḥ yat prabhāvaḥ ca iti tu puruṣaḥ iti ādi dvyābhyām iti vivekaḥ
translated: But who is that, and whose power it is is distinguished by the two verses beginning with Purusha.

original: tatra saptama īśvarasya dve prakṛtī parāpare kṣetrakṣetrajñalakṣaṇe upanyasya etadyonīni bhūtāni Gītā / ity uktam /
analyzed: tatra saptame īśvarasya dve prakṛtī parāpare kṣetra kṣetrajña lakṣaṇe upanyasya etad yonīni bhūtāni gītāni iti uktam
translated: There, in the seventh chapter, having presented the two natures of God, the higher and the lower, characterized as the field and the knower of the field, it is said: All beings have their source in these two.

original: tatrāparā prakṛtiḥ kṣetralakṣaṇā parā tu jīvalakṣaṇeti tayor anāditvam uktvā tadubhayayonitvaṃ bhūtānām ucyate prakṛtim iti /
analyzed: tatra aparā prakṛtiḥ kṣetra lakṣaṇā parā tu jīva lakṣaṇā iti tayoḥ anādi tvam uktvā tad ubhaya yoni tvam bhūtānām ucyate prakṛtim iti
translated: There, the lower nature is characterized by the field, but the higher is characterized by the individual soul. Having stated their beginninglessness, it is said that all beings have their source in both of them, with the words Prakriti and so on.

original: prakṛtir māyākhyā triguṇātmikā pārameśvarī śaktiḥ kṣetralakṣaṇā yā prāg aparā prakṛtir ity uktā /
analyzed: prakṛtiḥ māyā ākhyā triguṇa ātmikā pārameśvarī śaktiḥ kṣetra lakṣaṇā yā prāk aparā prakṛtiḥ iti uktā
translated: Prakriti, which is characterized by the field and was previously called the lower nature, is the power of the Supreme Lord, known as Maya, consisting of the three gunas.

original: yā tu parā prakṛtir jīvākhyā prāg uktā sa iha puruṣa ity ukta iti na pūrvāparavirodhaḥ /
analyzed: yā tu parā prakṛtiḥ jīva ākhyā prāk uktā saḥ iha puruṣaḥ iti uktaḥ iti na pūrva apara virodhaḥ
translated: But the higher nature, which was previously called the individual soul, is called the Purusha here. Thus there is no contradiction between the earlier and later statements.

original: prakṛtiṃ puruṣaṃ cobhāv api anādī eva viddhi /
analyzed: prakṛtim puruṣam ca ubhau api anādī eva viddhi
translated: Know that both Prakriti and Purusha are beginningless.

original: na vidyate ādiḥ kāraṇaṃ yayos tau /
analyzed: na vidyate ādiḥ kāraṇam yayoḥ tau
translated: They have no beginning, no cause.

original: tathā prakṛter anāditvaṃ sarvajagatkāraṇatvāt /
analyzed: tathā prakṛteḥ anādi tvam sarva jagat kāraṇatvāt
translated: Similarly, Prakriti is beginningless because it is the cause of the entire world.

original: tasyā api kāraṇasāpekṣatve 'navasthāprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: tasyāḥ api kāraṇa sāpekṣa tve navasthā prasaṅgāt
translated: If it too required a cause, there would be an infinite regress.

original: puruṣasyānāditvaṃ taddharmādharmaprayuktatvāt kṛtsnasya jagataḥ jātasya harṣaśokabhayasampratipatteḥ /
analyzed: puruṣasya anādi tvam tad dharma adharma prayukta tvāt kṛtsnasya jagataḥ jātasya harṣa śoka bhaya sampratipatteḥ
translated: The soul is beginningless because the entire world, which is produced by its qualities, virtue and vice, experiences joy, sorrow and fear.

original: anyathā kṛtahānyakṛtābhyāgamaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: anyathā kṛta hāni akṛta abhyāgama prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be the undesirable consequence of the loss of what is done and the acquisition of what is not done.

original: yataḥ prakṛtir anādir atas tasyā bhūtayonitvam uktaṃ prāg upapadyata ity āha vikārāṃś
analyzed: yatas prakṛtiḥ anādiḥ atas tasyāḥ bhūta yoni tvam uktam prāk upapadyate iti āha vikārān
translated: Since Nature is beginningless, therefore the statement made earlier that it is the source of the elements becomes reasonable. He says: And the modifications,

original: ca ṣoḍaśa pañca mahābhūtāny ekādaśendriyāṇi ca guṇāṃś ca sattvarajastamorūpān
analyzed: ca ṣoḍaśa pañca mahābhūtāni ekādaśa indriyāṇi ca guṇān ca sattva rajaḥ tamaḥ rūpān
translated: the sixteen, the five great elements and the eleven sense organs, and the qualities, which are of the nature of goodness, passion and ignorance,

original: sukhaduḥkhamohān prakṛtisaṃbhavān eva
analyzed: sukha duḥkha mohān prakṛti saṃbhavān eva
translated: the happiness, sorrow and delusion, know them to be born of Nature itself,

original: prakṛtikāraṇakān eva viddhi jānīhi ////
analyzed: prakṛti kāraṇakān eva viddhi jānīhi
translated: to be caused by Nature alone.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha:

original: paramātmānam uktvā kṣetrajñaśabdavācyaṃ jīvātmānaṃ vaktuṃ kutas tasya māyāsaṃsleṣaḥ /🔽kadā tadārambho 'bhūd ity apekṣāyām āha prakṛtiṃ māyāṃ puruṣaṃ jīvaṃ cobhāv apy anādī na vidyate ādi kāraṇaṃ yayos tathābhūtau viddhi anāder
analyzed: paramātmānam uktvā kṣetrajña śabda vācyam jīvātmānam vaktum kutas tasya māyā saṃsleṣaḥ  kadā tad ārambhaḥ bhūt iti apekṣāyām āha prakṛtim māyām puruṣam jīvam ca ubhau api anādī na vidyate ādi kāraṇam yayoḥ tathābhūtau viddhi anādeḥ
translated: Having described the Supreme Self, in order to describe the individual self, which is denoted by the word kshetrajna, he says, from where does its contact with Maya arise?

original: īśvarasya mama śaktitvāt /
analyzed: īśvarasya mama śakti tvāt
translated: When did its commencement take place? Anticipating this question, he says, know that both Nature, which is Maya, and the individual soul are beginningless, i.e., they have no beginning cause. In this way, they are such. They are my powers, of the beginningless God.

original: bhūmir āpo 'nalo vāyuḥ khaṃ mano buddhir eva ca /
analyzed: bhūmiḥ āpaḥ nalaḥ vāyuḥ kham manaḥ buddhiḥ eva ca
translated: Earth, water, fire, air, space, mind, and intellect,

original: ahaṅkāra itīyaṃ me bhinnā prakṛtir aṣṭadhā //
analyzed: ahaṅkāraḥ iti iyam me bhinnā prakṛtiḥ aṣṭadhā
translated: This is my Nature divided into eight parts, under the name of egoism.

original: apareyam itas tv anyāṃ prakṛtiṃ viddhi me parām /
analyzed: aparā iyam itas tu anyām prakṛtim viddhi me parām
translated: But different from this is My other Nature, which is supreme,

original: jīvabhūtāṃ mahābāho yayedaṃ dhāryate jagat // Gītā /
analyzed: jīva bhūtām mahā bāho yayā idam dhāryate jagat gītā
translated: and which is the source of the living beings, O mighty-armed one, by which this world is sustained.

original: iti madukter māyājīvayor api macchaktitvena anāditvāt tayoḥ saṃśleṣo 'pi anādir iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: iti mad ukteḥ māyā jīvayoḥ api mad śakti tvena anādi tvāt tayoḥ saṃśleṣaḥ api anādiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that because both Maya and the individual soul are My powers, they are beginningless, and therefore their union is also beginningless, as stated by Me.

original: tatra mithaḥ saṃśliṣṭayor api tayor vastutaḥ pārthakyam asti eva ity āha vikārāṃś
analyzed: tatra mithas saṃśliṣṭayoḥ api tayoḥ vastutas pārthakyam asti eva iti āha vikārān
translated: There, although they are mutually united, they are actually distinct from each other. This is stated by the word vibhajya (having divided).

original: ca dehendriyādīn guṇāṃś ca guṇapariṇāmān sukhaduḥkhaśokamohādīn prakṛtisambhūtān🔽prakṛtyudbhūtān viddhīti kṣetrākārapariṇatāyāḥ prakṛteḥ sakāśād bhinnam eva jīvaṃ
analyzed: ca deha indriya ādīn guṇān ca guṇa pariṇāmān sukha duḥkha śoka moha ādīn prakṛti sambhūtān  prakṛti udbhūtān viddhi iti kṣetra ākāra pariṇatāyāḥ prakṛteḥ sakāśāt bhinnam eva jīvam
translated: The modifications are the body, senses, etc., and the qualities are the transformations of the qualities, such as pleasure, pain, sorrow, delusion, etc., which originate from Nature.

original: viddhīti bhāvaḥ // //
analyzed: viddhi iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that one should know the individual soul to be distinct from Nature, which has transformed into the form of the field.

original: baladevaḥ / evaṃ mitho viviktasvabhāvayor anādyoḥ prakṛtijīvayoḥ saṃsargasyānādikālikatvaṃ
analyzed: baladevaḥ evam mithas vivikta svabhāvayoḥ anādyoḥ prakṛti jīvayoḥ saṃsargasya anādi kālika tvam
translated: Balarama: Thus, the beginninglessness of the union of Nature and the individual soul, which have distinct natures and are beginningless,

original: saṃsṛṣṭayos tayoḥ kāryabhedas tatsaṃsargasyānādikālikasya hetuś ca nirūpyate prakṛtim ity ādibhiḥ /
analyzed: saṃsṛṣṭayoḥ tayoḥ kārya bhedaḥ tad saṃsargasya anādi kālikasya hetuḥ ca nirūpyate prakṛtim iti ādibhiḥ
translated: and the difference in their effects when united, and the cause of that beginningless union are described by the words prakrtim (Nature), etc.

original: apir avadhṛtau /
analyzed: apiḥ avadhṛtau
translated: Api, even;

original: mithaḥ sampṛktau prakṛtipuruṣāv ubhāv anādyeva viddhi madīyaśaktitvān nityāv eva jānīhi /
analyzed: mithas sampṛktau prakṛti puruṣau ubhau anādya iva viddhi madīya śakti tvāt nityau eva jānīhi
translated: viddhi, know; ubhau, both; prakriti-purusau, Nature and the individual soul; mithah, mutually; samprakhyau, to be associated; an-adi-eva, from the very beginning; iti, thus; hi, because; ubhau, both; nityau, are eternal; mad-saktatau, by being attached to Me.

original: tayor macchaktitvaṃ tu puraivoktaṃ bhūmir āpaḥ ity ādinā /🔽anādisaṃsṛṣṭayor api tayoḥ svarūpabhedo 'stīty āśayenāh vikārān dehendriyādīn /
analyzed: tayoḥ mad śakti tvam tu purā eva uktam bhūmiḥ āpaḥ iti ādinā  anādi saṃsṛṣṭayoḥ api tayoḥ sva rūpa bhedaḥ sti iti āśayena āh vikārān deha indriya ādīn
translated: That both of them are My powers has been stated earlier in, 'Earth, water' (3.12), etc.🔽With the idea that, though associated from the very beginning, there is a difference in their nature, the Lord says, vikaran, the modifications, the body, the organs, etc.; and gunan, the qualities, happiness, sorrow, etc.

original: guṇāṃś sukhaduḥkhāni prakṛtisambhavān prākṛtān na tu jaivān viddhīti kṣetrātmanā pariṇatāyāḥ prakṛter anyo jīva iti darśitam ////
analyzed: guṇān sukha duḥkhāni prakṛti sambhavān prākṛtān na tu jaivān viddhi iti kṣetra ātmanā pariṇatāyāḥ prakṛteḥ anyaḥ jīvaḥ iti darśitam
translated: Viddhi, know; prakrti-sambhavan, to be born of Nature, to be natural, not artificial. Thus it has been shown that the individual soul is different from Nature which has transformed itself into the body of the field (of the organs).

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: (The individual soul is) the enjoyer of happiness and sorrow.

original: kāryakāraṇakartṛtve hetuḥ prakṛtir ucyate /
analyzed: kārya kāraṇa kartṛ tve hetuḥ prakṛtiḥ ucyate
translated: The cause of the doership of the body and the organs is said to be Nature.

original: puruṣaḥ sukhaduḥkhānāṃ bhoktṛtve hetur ucyate ////
analyzed: puruṣaḥ sukha duḥkhānām bhoktṛ tve hetuḥ ucyate
translated: The individual soul is said to be the cause of the experience of happiness and sorrow.

original: śrīdharaḥ / vikārāṇāṃ prakṛtisambhavatvaṃ darśayan puruṣasya saṃsārahetutvaṃ darśayati kāryeti /
analyzed: darśayan       darśayati
translated: Sri Sridhara: Showing that the modifications are born of Nature, the Lord shows that the individual soul is the cause of worldly existence in, 'The cause...' etc.

original: kāryaṃ śarīram /
analyzed: kāryam śarīram
translated: The body is the effect.

original: kāraṇāni sukhaduḥkhasādhanānīndriyāṇi /
analyzed: kāraṇāni sukha duḥkha sādhanāni indriyāṇi
translated: The organs are the causes, the instruments of happiness and sorrow.

original: teṣāṃ kartṛtve tadākārapariṇāme prakṛtir hetur ucyate kapilādibhiḥ /
